channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: After a Quarter-Century of Legal Wrangling in India, a Rock Opera Can Go on
item.description: A ban in Kerala state on a school’s staging of “Jesus Christ Superstar” dating to 1990 has been lifted, though no productions are now scheduled.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR

item.title: 2 New Ebola Vaccines Pass Important Early Test, Researchers Say
item.description: The vaccines protected monkeys from the virus that has killed thousands in Africa. Tests in humans will probably begin this summer.
item.dc:creator: DENISE GRADY
item.media:credit: Michael Stravato for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thomas W. Geisbert, an Ebola expert at the University of Texas Medical Branch in Galveston, in his office.

item.title: U.S. Deports Salvadoran General Accused in ’80s Killings
item.description: The expulsion of Gen. Carlos Eugenio Vides Casanova culminates a battle by rights advocates to hold him accountable for his role in the 1980 murders of four American churchwomen.
item.dc:creator: JULIA PRESTON
item.media:description: General Carlos Eugenio Vides Casanova outside the federal courthouse in Palm Beach, Fla., in October 2000.

item.title: U.S. Defense Chief Warns of Al Qaeda’s Gains in Yemen
item.description: Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter acknowledged Wednesday that the Qaeda affiliate in Yemen had exploited the tumult partly created by the Saudi-led airstrikes there to capture territory.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: A house destroyed by an airstrike in the village of Bait Rejal, Yemen, on Tuesday.

item.title: Judge Drops 2 Terror Attacks From Arab Bank Case
item.description: A federal judge granted the bank’s motion arguing that the plaintiffs had not sufficiently demonstrated that the terrorist group Hamas had committed the attacks.
item.dc:creator: STEPHANIE CLIFFORD

item.title: Sex Education in Europe Turns to Urging More Births
item.description: Disconcerting forecasts showing aging populations and increasing burdens on social services are weighing on governments throughout the region.
item.dc:creator: DANNY HAKIM
item.media:credit: Sofie Amalie Klougart for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students at a Copenhagen school during a discussion of sex led by a group seeking to raise Denmark's birth rate.

item.title: Rights Advocates in India Call for Inquiry Into Killing of Loggers
item.description: Indian groups urged the authorities to explain the police action that led to the deaths of 20 loggers said to be illegally cutting red sandalwood trees.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR

item.title: C.I.A. Director Says Iran’s Economic Peril Helped Drive Nuclear Deal
item.description: John O. Brennan told an audience at Harvard that a key to the deal was the election of Iranian President Hassan Rouhani, who was able to persuade Ayatollah Ali Khamenei of the need to negotiate.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: John O. Brennan, director of the Central Intelligence Agency, at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard on Tuesday.

item.title: Putin Meets With Alexis Tsipras of Greece, Raising Eyebrows in Europe
item.description: The Russian president said that the visit by the Greek prime minister “could not have come at a better time.”
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and LIZ ALDERMAN

item.title: Defense Secretary Urges Restraint in South China Sea Disputes
item.description: Amid new evidence of reclamation activity in the Asia-Pacific region, Ashton B. Carter, the U.S. secretary of defense, warned against Chinese militarization in territorial disputes.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: A satellite image from March 16 shows dredgers working at the northernmost reclamation site of Mischief Reef, part of the Spratly Islands, in the South China Sea.

item.title: Marine Le Pen, Leader of France’s National Front Party, Splits With Her Father, Its Founder
item.description: Ms. Le Pen called recent comments by her father, Jean-Marie Le Pen, “political suicide” and an attempt to harm the far-right party.
item.dc:creator: SUZANNE DALEY
item.media:description: Marine Le Pen, the head of France’s far-right National Front, has recently split with her father and the founder of her party, Jean-Marie Le Pen, right, over his controversial comments.

item.title: U.S. Coalition Service Member Killed in Afghanistan Shooting
item.description: The attack, by an Afghan soldier at a guard post who began shooting at troops, occurred in the eastern city of Jalalabad.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN
item.media:description: An Afghan soldier outside the provincial governor's compound in Jalalabad on Wednesday. A soldier opened fire at coalition troops nearby, killing one service member.

item.title: Iraq Starts Drive Against ISIS, but Reports on Scale Differ
item.description: Some local officials said it was the beginning of a major offensive in western Anbar Province, though others said such a description was premature.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: Iraqi security forces searching for Islamic State fighters on Saturday in the Haouz neighborhood of Ramadi, Iraq.

item.title: 5 Women’s Rights Activists in China Are Being Held Illegally, Lawyers Say
item.description: The police have missed a deadline for filing a request for a formal arrest of the women, the lawyers for three of them said.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Li Tingting, who works under the pseudonym Li Maizi, has been known in advocacy circles since 2012.

item.title: Royal Dutch Shell to Buy BG Group for Nearly $70 Billion
item.description: The BG Group is a major player in liquefied natural gas, and if the deal is completed, the sale would be a rare bright spot for energy deal makers.
item.dc:creator: STANLEY REED and MICHAEL J. de la MERCED
item.media:description: A Shell gas station in London. Royal Dutch Shell said on Wednesday that a deal to buy the BG Group would add 25 percent to its proven reserves of oil and gas.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Rescue Mission in Yemen Proves to Be Boon for Chinese Military’s Image
item.description: It was the first time China had deployed warships to carry out such a rescue, and the fact that so many people from other countries were ferried to safety was seen as polishing the country’s image.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: A People's Liberation Army medic checked foreigners preparing for evacuation from Aden, Yemen, on April 2.

item.title: Palestinian Stabs 2 Israeli Soldiers and Is Killed
item.description: One soldier was seriously injured and the other was lightly wounded in the attack in the West Bank that broke several weeks of relative calm.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Israeli security forces removed the body of a Palestinian man who attacked two soldiers on Wednesday, near Sinjil, West Bank. The man was shot to death by security forces at the scene.

item.title: Lens Blog: The Evidence of Mexico’s Missing
item.description: After 43 students disappeared in Mexico, Christopher Gregory went there to document the traces left by countless others who have been killed or kidnapped.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ
item.media:description: A team of family members combing the mountains near Cocula, near Iguala, Mexico, after receiving an anonymous tip that there had been cartel activity in the area.

item.title: For Eager Cubans, Big Opening in U.S. Relations Is More Like a Crack
item.description: More than three months after a thaw with the United States was announced, supplies remain short in Cuba, and weak technology impedes progress.
item.dc:creator: RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD
item.media:description: A cultural center in Havana that offers free Wi-Fi, a rarity in Cuba. “Everybody thinks the opening with the Americans will improve a lot of things, even the Internet,” said Lieban Esthir, a 27-year-old using Wi-Fi at the center. “Let’s hope so.”

item.title: Latin America Trip Will Test Obama’s Push for Ties With Cuba
item.description: As President Obama prepared for a summit meeting in Panama, White House officials signaled a decision was near on whether to remove Cuba from a list of terrorism sponsors.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
